intro: Teucrium persicum, commonly known as Persian germander, is a perennial herb native to regions of the Middle East and Central Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves with hairy surfaces. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pink or purple, arranged in whorls along the stem, and bloom in summer. It is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and antiseptic properties.
